passages.text: The European General Retail sector was down \(- 2\%\) this week, underperforming the broader market. Most of our coverage was in negative territory led by the UK names, as the theme of a potentially softer UK consumer into the end of the year gained traction, exacerbated by particularly soft Asda income tracker data (slowest rate of growth since May- 23 and, perhaps more importantly, middle income quintile spending power going backwards you for the first time in two years). We published our Aug chartbook this week where we discussed this theme in more detail. Kingfisher \((- 6\%)\) and ABF \((- 6\%)\) were the worst performers, with both also dragged by a broker downgrade. Soft Polish retail sales data for the DIY category was also unhelpful for the former. \(\mathsf{H}\& \mathsf{M}\) \((- 1\%)\) and ITX (flat) slightly outperformed, helped by US retail reporting that was overall solid, including robust trading commentary in Jul and Aug, albeit a clear theme from the US retail group was also higher margin pressure from tariffs than previously communicated (see our quotes section for collated comments on both current trading and tariff pressure from the US clothing retailers). The E- commerce sector was down \(- 1\%\) , in line with the broader market. Zalando (flat) slightly outperformed, possibly helped by strong Polish clothing retail sales data (recall that Zalando has DD% sales exposure to Poland).

I will be marketing in London next week (4 & 5 Sep) with my colleague Borja Olcese, discussing our latest views across both General & Food Retail post the summer, and conviction ideas for H2. Please reach out if you would like a slot.
Specialist Sales contact details:
See page 19 for analyst certification and important disclosures, including non- US analyst disclosures.

J.P. Morgan does and seeks to do business with companies covered in its research reports. As a result, investors should be aware that the firm may have a conflict of interest that could affect the objectivity of this report. Investors should consider this report as only a single factor in making their investment decision.

We published our Aug- 25 Chartbook. This month did you see that...? (1) UK BRC Non- Food retail sales were still positive in Jul, BDO data also show growth in Aug- to- date and UK consumer confidence \(+2\) pts in Aug. (2) However, the potential for a weakening UK consumer into the year end has been a clear theme... (3) ...with Asda income tracker growth \((+2.4\%)\) the slowest since May- 23 (see more below) and middle quintile disposable income in decline you for the first time since Sep- 23, housing market data inconsistent (including RICS showing mostly deteriorating trends - new buyer enquiries turned negative), and UK labour market data softening (consistent with JPM's employment nowcast of \(- 0.6\%\) ). (4) Most European clothing markets (including the UK) are facing a particularly tough comparative in Sep. (5) French DIY sales were very weak in Jul at \(- 9\%\) you. This left the French DIY market in May- Jul (Kingfisher's Q2 26) at \(- 3\%\) vs \(- 4\%\) in the group's Q1. The market is therefore tracking softer than our French Q2 LFL forecast for flat (Q1: \(- 3\%\) ). See much more here: Rolling UK consumer a building narrative (+ mind the Sep comp).

European Consumer Confidence (European Commission data) for Aug declined slightly, with Germany and France deteriorating while Italy improved. Numbers in detail: EU overall - 14.8 in Aug vs - 14.5 in Jul. By country: Germany - 10.6 in Aug vs - 8.4 in Jul (see below for GfK German consumer confidence forecast for Sep); France - 18.5 in Aug vs - 16.8 in Jul (INSEE measure also reported this week showed a deterioration to 87 in Aug vs 88 in Jul, this came in below cons for 89); and Italy - 16.8 in Aug vs - 17.0 in Jul.

German Consumer Confidence (GfK measure) for Sep (forecast) deteriorated by c.2 pts to - 23.6 vs - 21.7 in Aug (revised), below cons for - 21.5. GfK commented that "A key reason for the noticeable decline in income expectations is likely to be growing concerns about job security... Employment pessimism has also risen significantly among consumers this month". GfK also commented that "In addition to concerns about possible job losses, ongoing uncertainty about the future development of consumer prices is also likely to be playing a role among consumers. The geopolitical situation and the US government's tariff policy are fueling fears that energy prices, among other things, could rise again".

German retail sales (TextilWirtschaft) data for w/c 18 Aug \(+4\%\) yoy vs prior week - \(2\%\) (despite what was a \(+\) DD% comparative). Aug- to- date is now averaging \(+1\%\) yoy vs Jul reported - \(1\%\) . TW referenced "not too hot, not too cold" weather combined with promo activity that encouraged sales. One retailer commented that "we have more summer merchandise to reduce than a year ago." In addition, TW commented that "A strong demand impulse also seems to come from the new collections."

Spanish Jul clothing (personal equipment) sales from INE showed a slowdown yoy. Jul sales \(+2.7\%\) yoy/ \(+5.4\%\) yoy/ \(+7.9\%\) yoy (restated) / \(+1.2\%\) yoy2. As a reminder, Inditex and Primark (ABF) derive c.15% of sales each from Spain.

Polish retail sales \(+4.8\%\) yoy in Jul (across all categories) vs \(+2.1\%\) in Jun. The "Other Goods" category (which includes DIY sales, and which Kingfisher has recently communicated is therefore a better read to its business than the Furniture & Household Appliances) declined \(- 4.0\%\) yoy (vs - \(2.2\%\) in Jun). This took the Kingfisher Q2 26 quarter in Poland to c. \(- 5\%\) on average vs c. \(- 7\%\) in Q1. For Q2 we forecast Kingfisher Polish LFL sales of \(- 3.0\%\) vs \(- 3.2\%\) in Q1. Separately, clothing sales in Poland were \(+\) DD% for a second consecutive month \((+13\%\) vs \(+10\%\) in Jun). Recall that Zalando generates a DD% of sales in Poland. See more from JPM
Apost E. Joufova here.

tailwind. Management confirmed expectations for Q3 pricing to be flat yoy (vs the Q2 decline). For FY 25, management raised guidance, now expecting sales \(+5.7\%\) yoy (previously \(+3.6\%\) , BBG cons \(+5\%\) ), and operating margin of \(13.0 - 13.5\%\) (previously \(12.5 - 13.5\%\) , BBG cons \(12.8\%\) ). Updated margin guidance included \(\) 40m\(of net (of mitigations) incremental tariff headwinds, taking the total expected net tariff headwinds for the year to\) \ \(90m\) , which would represent c.170ps of margin. We estimate that this would imply a tariff impact of 350- 400bps on an annualised basis. With regards to the tariff guidance being on a net basis, management referenced mitigating actions including country of origin optimisation, vendor negotiations, open efficiencies and also price. On price though, management was clear that at this stage it is not planning broad- based price increases (although it also commented that "our customer doesn't come to us for price. We're not necessarily going to chase traffic and conversion through price." See more from JPM analyst M. Boss here.

- Urban Outfitters reported Q2 25 (to end Jul) results with Q2 sales \(+11\%\) yoy (cons \(+9\%\) ). Tone on current trading was upbeat. Management referenced "gently raising prices" as a potential tariff mitigation strategy. Retail LFL sales \(+6\%\) yoy (cons \(+4\%\) ), with positive comp growth across all banners for the second consecutive quarter. Specifically: Free People LFL \(+7\%\) (cons \(+5\%\) ); Anthropologie LFL \(+6\%\) (cons \(+6\%\) ); and Urban Outfitters brand \(+4\%\) (cons \(+2\%\) ). Within the core Urban Outfitters brand (LFL \(+4\%\) in Q2 vs Q1 \(+2\%\) ), Europe LFL sales increased \(+11\%\) with management commenting that "this quarter's results were driven by solid growth in both the UK, and continental Europe". Core North America LFL sales inflected positively to \(+0.3\%\) growth (Q1 \(-4\%\) ) as headwinds associated with clearance abated into Jul, resulting in underlying strength of regular price selling. Gross margin was up \(+113\) bps yoy to \(37.6\%\) (cons for \(37.5\%\) ) driven by lower markdowns and leverage in occupancy costs. On current trading, management commented that "success for all brands has continued August to date and we are planning to deliver high single-digit growth in total sales for Q3. Both consumer demand and our execution remain strong. The only major headwind we currently face is the uncertainty surrounding tariff rates". Management provided guidance for Q3 total sales \(+\) HSD\% yoy (cons \(+7\%\) ) including \(+\) MSD\% LFL sales across all three banners, and gross margin flat yoy (cons \(+18\) bps) with lower product markdowns and occupancy leverage offset by tariff headwinds. Furthermore, management expects FY 25 gross margin to be up \(+100\) bps yoy (previously \(+50\) - \(100\) bps yoy, cons \(+83\) bps yoy) supported by lower product markdowns and favourable occupancy leverage, despite embedding an incremental tariff headwind into H2 25 guidance (-75bps net tariff headwind vs previously expectations for - 20bps). The net headwind is post expecting some price increases. Management commented that "the teams are being very thoughtful about [raising prices]. We're looking to protect opening price points and only targeting areas where we believe we could gently raise some prices without significantly affecting the overall customer experience". See more from JPM Analyst M. Boss here.

- Kohl's reported better-than-expected Q2 25 (to end-Jul) results, with Aug off to a good start in Q3. Additional tariff headwinds are now expected into the back half of the year. Net sales -5% yoy (cons -6%), including LFL sales -4% yoy (cons -5%). Management cited a sequential improvement through the quarter driven by improved traffic (notably in the digital channel) and proprietary brand sales - Jul exited the quarter with flat LFL sales growth. Gross margin was up +28bps yoy to 39.9% (in line with cons) driven by category mix benefit, increased private label brand penetration, and strong inventory management. On current trading

management commented that "As far as August is concerned, we're actually off to a good start here in the first month of the quarter". On outlook, management raised guidance for FY 25 LFL sales and operating margin guidance, now looking for FY 25 LFL sales \(- 5\%\) to \(- 6\%\) yoy (previously \(- 5\%\) to \(- 7\%\) , cons \(- 6\%\) ) and FY 25 operating margin of \(2.5 - 2.7\%\) (previously \(2.2 - 2.6\%\) , cons \(2.5\%\) ). Within this, management expects FY 25 gross margin to expand by \(+30\) bps yoy (previous guidance for \(+30 - 50\) bps yoy, cons flat) with a benefit from increased private brand penetration offset by additional tariff headwinds expected into the back half of the year (Q4 skewed). Management commented that the gross margin guidance "gives us some flexibility to really make sure that we're driving that value". Management characterised the H2 25 outlook as a "prudent approach to our financial outlook for the remainder of the year" given the macro environment and noted that the lower- to middle- income customers remain the most challenged and are increasingly "prioritising value and trading down into lower opening price point products". See more from JPM analyst M. Boss here.

- Burlington reported Q2 25 (to end-Jul) results ahead of expectations and upgraded guidance. Current trading was described as solid. Management referenced incremental tariff pressure into H2. Total LFL sales \(+5\%\) yoy (cons \(+2\%\) ). Management commented that "The trend in Q2 started out slowly... but then our trend picked up in June and July as the weather normalized". Traffic was flat in the quarter with LFL sales driven by increased transaction size and pricing up \(+MSD\%\) yoy. Gross margin increased \(+90\) bps yoy to \(43.7\%\) (cons \(42.9\%\) ) driven by lower markdowns, supported by faster inventory turn and improved inventory management, as well as freight tailwinds, which together more than offset tariff pressures. On current trading, management commented that "early back-to-school selling in July was especially strong... momentum has moderated somewhat since then, but still for August month-to-date, I would describe our sales trend for back-to-school businesses as solid". Management provided guidance for Q3 total sales \(+5 - 7\%\) yoy (BBG cons \(+9\%\) ) including LFL sales \(+0 - 2\%\) (BBG cons \(+3\%\) ). Q3 adjusted EBIT margin is expected to be -20bps to flat yoy (BBG cons \(+6\) bps) with gross margin expected to be lower yoy "due to the impact of tariffs". For FY 25 overall management raised guidance and is now looking for total sales \(+7 - 8\%\) yoy (previously \(+6 - 8\%\) , BBG cons \(+8\%\) ) including LFL sales \(+1 - 2\%\) yoy (previously \(+0 - 2\%\) , BBG cons \(+1\%\) ) and adjusted EBIT margin \(+20 - 40\) bps yoy (previously \(+0 - 30\) bps, BBG cons \(+31\) bps). Management commented "we are not flowing through the entire earnings beat. This is because of incremental tariff pressure in the back half. Tariffs for most countries are higher now than when we last discussed earnings guidance on our Q1 call in May". Management also commented on mitigation strategies including "continuously working and negotiating with our vendor partners on cost, adjusting and remixing our assortment, selectively raising retails [prices], driving a faster inventory turn to drive lower markdowns, accelerating plan savings initiatives, and then just aggressively going after incremental expense savings across the P&L". Management noted that it has observed "selective" and "restrained" price increases amongst competitors. Interestingly, management also noted that it is "not seeing any issues [with lower-income shopper] at this point". See more from JPM analyst M. Boss here.

- Victoria's Secret reported Q2 25 results (to end-Jul) and upgraded sales guidance. Net sales \(+3\%\) yoy (BBG cons \(-1\%\) ), including LFL \(+4\%\) yoy (BBG cons flat). International sales were up \(+22\%\) yoy (BBG cons \(+3\%\) ). Within this, management noted that "retail comps were up high single-digits, reflecting the strength of our global partnership and growing brand relevance". Recall that UK

retailer Next owned a \(51\%\) stake in the UK&I Victoria's Secret JV. Management also noted particular strength in the China business driven by the digital channel. Gross margin was \(+20\) bps yoy to \(35.6\%\) (BBG cons \(35.1\%\) ) driven by disciplined inventory management and "evolving promotional approach" leading to more regular price selling, offsetting tariff headwinds. Management commented that "we've really made a conscious effort to pull back on promos and the traditional discounts. We expect that to continue into the back half. That is one of our mitigation levers on tariffs, but it's coupled with our product newness [and] really driving more regular price sales. On pricing, management commented "we're looking where we see opportunities that can still create that value, but we're being mindful of entry price points and sort of not to exceed price points. So first and foremost is promos and then select strategic price modifications where it makes sense". Pricing levels were up \(1\%\) yoy in the quarter. On current trading management commented "the business was strong throughout the quarter and accelerated in July and into August". Management also referenced a still uncertain macro environment. Looking ahead, management provided Q3 guidance for sales \(+3 - 5\%\) yoy to \(\) 1.39- \(\) 1.42bn\(BBG cons + 1\%\) ) and Q3 gross margin down - 80bps yoy to \(34.0\%\) (BBG cons \(34.9\%\) ), including estimated net tariff pressure of c.140bps, partially offset by a continued focus on promotional strategy and buying and occupancy expense leverage from sales growth. For FY 25, management upgraded guidance for sales to \(\) 6.3bn\(to\) \ \(6.4bn\) (previous \(\) 6.2bn\(to\) \ \(6.3bn\) , cons \(\) 6.2bn\(vs FY 24\) \ \(6.2bn\) ) and reiterated operating income \(\) 270m\(to\) \ \(320m\) (BBG cons \(\) 295m\(), including an updated net tariff impact of\) \ \(100m\) , i.e. 160bps of margin at the midpoint ( \(\) 50m\(higher than the estimated net tariff impact in previous guidance), reflecting tariff mitigation of c.\) \ \(70m\) i.e. 110bps of sales at the midpoint of guidance. Victoria's Secret is covered by JPM Analyst M. Boss.

- Gap reported Q2 25 (to end-Jul) results which were perceived as more mixed, albeit current trading commentary was robust. Guidance on tariff headwinds widened vs previous expectations. Sales on a LFL basis increased \(+1\%\) yoy (cons \(+2\%\) ) although management referenced "healthy" traffic. Selling prices were confirmed as being in growth in Q2, which is expected to continue in H2 25. Gross margin -140bps yoy to \(41.2\%\) (cons \(42.0\%\) ) dragged as it lapped the benefit of incremental sales in Q2 24 (from a revenue share agreement with a credit card partner), in addition to markdown pressure associated with deliberately clearing Athleta inventory given the brand's top-line underperformance. On current trading, management commented "as it relates to back-to-school, third quarter is off to a strong start... we really did start to see July accelerate with more seasonal weather and the drop of our back-to-school product. And August has really continued that momentum". Guidance was provided for Q3 25 sales to be \(+1.5 - 2.5\%\) yoy (cons \(+2\%\) ). Management expects Q3 gross margin -150bps to -170bps yoy (cons -150bps) including an estimated 200bps of net tariff impact. For FY 25, management reiterated guidance for net sales \(+1 - 2\%\) yoy (cons \(+2\%\) ) and outlined operating margin expectations of \(6.7 - 7.0\%\) (cons \(6.9\%\) ) including an estimated 100-110bps net tariff impact (previously 65bps to 100bps). Management commented that mitigation plans include adjustments to sourcing, manufacturing, assortments and targeted pricing. On pricing specifically, management added that "while pricing is a lever to manage AUR, it's one of many we've been using to manage margin over-time. Other levers include assortment mix, full price sell-through, promotions and inventory management". Management also commented that "We do not currently expect the annualization of tariffs in 2026 to cause further operating income declines next year and we expect to mitigate the full impact of tariffs over time". See more from JPM
analyst M. Boss here.

- Spanish clothing retailer Mango filed its UK accounts for FY 24 (to end-Dec). Sales rose \(+6\%\) yoy to reach £128m (recall FY 24 group sales \(+8\%\) yoy or \(+12\%\) ex-FX supported by c.10% new space). Gross margin fell 80bps yoy to 46.3%. This contributed to a decline in the operating profit margin of 120bps to 3.1%. Indeed, operating profit fell c.23% in absolute terms to £4.0m. Looking ahead, management commented that "It is expected that online activity will stabilise while store sales continue to grow". The retailer had over 80 stores in the UK at FY 24 year-end. Management referenced plans to open new stores in the UK in FY 25. Recall the group had previously confirmed that it is planning to open 20 new stores in the UK in 2025 as part of the 2024-2026 strategic growth plan (we discussed Mango's global Strategic Plan in our PODCAST last year here). On outlook, management commented that "the directors hope for growth in the future as well as to improve the financial results of the company...the current economic conditions create uncertainty over the level of demand within the retail sector". For context, Mango group sales increased by 12% ex-FX in FY 24 (supported by 10% new space) to €3.3bn, meaning that the UK represented c.5% group sales. In H1 25 Mango sales increased by 14% ex-FX.

- Owners of UK clothing retailer New Look (2.5% market share with c.340 stores) 
- Alcentra and Brait 
- have reportedly (Sky) appointed bankers to oversee a strategic review and potential sale of the business. Alcentra and Brait have owned the business since Oct-20. A New Look spokesperson reportedly commented that "Management are focused on running the business and executing the strategy for long-term growth... The company is performing well, with strong momentum driven by a successful summer trading period and notable online market share gains."

- Chinese ecommerce retailer, PDD Holdings - owner of Temu - posted stronger-than-expected Q2 25 (to end-Jun) results, although the share price reaction was muted as management emphasised that current profitability is unsustainable given plans for longer-term investments. Across the group Q2 25 revenue was up \(+7\%\) yoy (vs \(+10\%\) in Q1 25). PDD's disclosure on Temu continues to be very limited, although JPM China Internet analyst, Andre Chang, thinks data points suggest that it is still achieving fast growth even amid the US/China dispute over tariffs. For the overall group in Q3, JPM expects margins to drop (with a question mark over 2026) with one of four key factors being Temu marketing spending. See more from JPM China Internet analyst, Andre Chang here and here.

- Debenhams group (previously boohoo) released FY 25 (to end-Feb) results. Recall that the group is pursuing a sale of the recently relaunched PLT brand (which represented c.31% of GMV post returns in FY 25, and was slightly loss marking by c.£-2m at the EBITDA level). FY 25 GMV was down -8% yoy (BBG cons -4%) and total sales -17% yoy (BBG cons -14%). Excluding the PLT brand, GMV was up +1% yoy and total sales -12% yoy. Management referenced "the standout performance" of the Debenhams brand with GMV +34% yoy. Management also commented that "strong growth in categories such as Beauty & Home have strengthened the breadth of the offer. Youth Brands' performance has been impacted by cost-of-living challenges". Gross margin was down -100bps yoy to 50.7% (-50bps yoy ex PLT) vs BBG cons 50.9% driven by increased promotional activity primarily in Youth Brands "to drive trade in a difficult consumer environment", offsetting the mix benefit of increased marketplace revenues with a higher gross margin. EBITDA -33% yoy to £39.6m (or ex PLT +3% yoy to £41.6m) vs cons £40.4m. EBIT remained a loss, although improved yoy to £-21m (BBG cons £-36m). Management also discussed how it has "significantly reduced the capital intensity of the business. We have faced into legacy stock issues and reduced our stock holding by more than 50%. We have stopped unnecessary capital expenditure and reduced capex by more than 50%. Further reductions will be delivered this financial year". On guidance, management expects H1 26 EBITDA (from continuing operations, that is ex-PLT) to be ahead of H1 25 (cons £20.5m, H1 25 EBITDA £20.8m). Management commented that "the UK consumer environment is challenging, seems to be getting more challenging, and lots of talk about it continuing to be challenging going forward" but commented that the UK government considering changes to the de minimis rule could present a potential opportunity. On pricing in the US in response to tariffs, management commented that "we've obviously priced up in order to protect ourselves from tariffs associated with China... We have seen a slowdown in our US performance in those markets, and we've taken appropriate action from a margin and a marketing point of view to protect ourselves". On the potential sale of the PLT brand, management commented that "We've noted with interest some of the interesting changing dynamics of macroeconomic situation relating to that fast fashion world, notably with the changes that have taken place in North America and the impact of that has had on a number of major global players... we see the opportunity to potentially realize significant value through a potential sale to a strategic partner of our PLT plans". The group is also assessing long-term options for the US and Burnley distribution sites "to enhance efficiency and ensure alignment with our stock-lite strategy".

"It does feel like there is more clarity on this [tariffs] now than there was a couple of months ago. So it wouldn't be surprising if retail prices were to go up across the industry in the back- half of the year. Now, of course, we know that our customer is very, very price- sensitive. We saw what happened with their discretionary spending levels when the cost of living increased in 2022. It was not good for us. So the prospect of higher inflation, especially if it spreads to non- discretionary categories like groceries, makes us very nervous, and it's another reason to be cautious on the rest of the year."
Michael O Sullivan, CEO, Burlington, 28/08/2025
Source: Company earnings call

"Essentially, our fall guidance reflects our best estimation of the net impacts of tariffs. So tariffs put significant pressure on, but we've worked very hard to identify offsetting actions. And these offsets include continuously working and negotiating with our vendor partners on cost, adjusting and remixing our assortment, selectively raising retails [prices], driving a faster inventory turn to drive lower markdowns, accelerating plan savings initiatives, and then just aggressively going after incremental expense savings across the P&L."
Kristin Wolfe, CFO, Burlington, 28/08/2025
Source: Company earnings call

"...industry- level pricing, the answer is yes, we are hearing and in some cases, we are seeing that competitors are taking up retail prices. So far, though, I would say that those price increases have been quite selective and quite restrained. Now I suspect there are a few reasons for that. Part of it may just be the time lag between imports arriving in the country and those goods showing up in stores, but also my sense is that wholesalers and retailers have been reluctant to make decisions on raising prices until they know what the final tariff rates are going to be."
Michael O Sullivan, CEO, Burlington, 28/08/2025
Source: Company earnings call
"...I want to emphasize that the cost pressure from tariffs is real."
Michael O Sullivan, CEO, Burlington, 28/08/2025
Source: Company earnings call

"As a global leader with the benefit of scale and brand momentum, we are moving swiftly with our mitigation plans, which include adjustments to our sourcing, manufacturing, assortments and targeted pricing... As it relates to pricing, as we said on our last call, we are approaching our pricing strategy as we always do, considering the various inputs while maintaining the overall value proposition for our consumers. And while pricing is a lever to manage AUR, it's one of many we've been using to manage margin over- time."
Katrina O'Connell, CFO, Gap Inc, 29/08/2025
Source: Company earnings call
"...we expect to mitigate the full impact of tariffs over time."
Katrina O'Connell, CFO, Gap Inc, 29/08/2025
Source: Company earnings call

"As of today, and based on new assumptions, we believe the impact for the second half of the year could be approximately 75 basis points to gross margins. Our teams continue to work on mitigation strategies, including negotiating better terms with our vendors, diversifying our countries of origin, changing our mode of transportation from air to ocean, and strategically adjusting pricing to minimize the impact on our customers."
Frank Conforti, CFO, Urban Outfitters, 28/08/2025
Source: Company earnings call

"As it relates to pricing, honestly, we have a sort of four-pronged approach, and pricing is really the last piece. And that's intentional. We're focused on protecting that customer experience as much as we possibly can...So first, our first piece there is negotiating better terms with our vendors. Second is going to be shifting our countries of origin where possible. Third is going to be adjusting our mode of transportation from air to ocean. And lastly, is going to be gently raising prices. And what I want to stress there is that the teams are being very thoughtful about the final step. We're looking to protect opening price points and only targeting areas where we believe we could gently raise some prices without significantly affecting the overall customer experience."
Frank Conforti, CFO, Urban Outfitters, 28/08/2025
Source: Company earnings call

"I would say, as the tariffs do come through, there is going to be a weight in the back half of the year. But I think we have ways based on how we see that penetration change to offset it. So I'd say it's pretty balanced between the two quarters, Q3 and Q4, in terms of how we see the margin coming in. But again, that's why we took it to the low end of the range. We had thought there was definitely some more upside here, as we obviously guided 30% to 50% earlier in the year. But now, given the changes that we've seen, we've brought the margin down so we can navigate it. So we can still ensure that we are being competitive in pricing and that we can drive value to the consumer in the back half of the year."
Jill Timm, CFO, Kohl's, 27/08/2025
Source: Company earnings call

"we've really made a conscious effort to pull back on promos and the traditional discounts. We expect that to continue into the back half. That is one of our mitigation levers on tariffs, but it's coupled with our product newness [and] really driving more regular-price sales. On pricing management commented "we're looking where we see opportunities that can still create that value, but we're being mindful of entry price points and sort of not to exceed price points. So first and foremost is promos and then select strategic price modifications where it makes sense."
Scott Sekella, CFO, Victoria's Secret, 28/08/2025
Source: Company earnings call

"Our guidance for the full year 2025 now assumes net tariff impact of approximately \(\) 100\(million, which reflects tariff mitigation of approximately\) \ \(70\) million. Our projected net tariff impact of \(\) 100\(million in 2025 is up\) \ \(50\) million versus our assumption embedded in our previous guidance...With approximately \(\) 10\$ million of net tariff impact already recognized in the first half of the year, our guidance assumes approximately \(\) 20\$ million of net tariff pressure in the third quarter, with \(\) 70\$ million impacting Q4."
Scott Sekella, CFO, Victoria's Secret, 28/08/2025
Source: Company earnings call

"Our impact mitigation efforts include optimizing costs with vendors further diversifying our sourcing, ensuring we have the most efficient air versus ocean freight mix possible, and implementing a combination of select pricing adjustments through more targeted promotions and strategic price modifications where we see a value proposition gap in the marketplace."
Scott Sekella, CFO, Victoria's Secret, 28/08/2025
Source: Company earnings call

"As discussed in May, we do not anticipate broad- based ticket price increases this year and have not assumed meaningful AUR mitigation in our outlook. Net of planned actions, the assumed tariffs carry a cost impact of around \(\) 90\$ million for 2025, impacting our full year operating margin outlook by 170 basis points at the midpoint of our sales outlook."
Robert Ball, CFO, Abercrombie & Fitch, 27/08/2025
Source: Company earnings call
"Our customer doesn't come to us for price. We're not necessarily going to chase traffic and conversion through price."
Robert Ball, CFO, Abercrombie & Fitch, 27/08/2025
Source: Company earnings call

"... we've obviously priced up in order to protect ourselves from tariffs associated with China... We have seen a slowdown in our US performance in those markets, and we've taken appropriate action from a margin and a marketing point of view to protect ourselves."
Phil Ellis, CEO, Debenhams, 27/08/2025
Source: Company earnings call

"Key questions remain [with regards to removal of the de minimis exemption], particularly regarding who will have to pay the tariffs, how, what additional data will be required, and how data will be transmitted to US Customs."
DHL Europe, 25/08/2025
Source: The Guardian
